thread.title: Harbaugh, U-M players de-emphasize MSU rivalry
thread.title_full: Harbaugh, U-M players de-emphasize MSU rivalry

title: Harbaugh, U-M players de-emphasize MSU rivalry
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Harbaugh, U-M players de-emphasizing MSU rivalry The tone at today's Michigan football news conference was a lack of concern over Michigan State's beatdowns the past two years. Post to Facebook Harbaugh, U-M players de-emphasizing MSU rivalry The tone at today's Michigan football news conference was a lack of concern over Michigan State's beatdowns the past two years. Check out this story on Freep.com: http://on.freep.com/1LqXbAH Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 16 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Harbaugh, U-M players de-emphasizing MSU rivalry Mark Snyder, Detroit Free Press 2:57 p.m. EDT October 12, 2015 Michigan football coach Jim Harbaugh greets players coming off the field after a touchdown against Northwestern in Ann Arbor on Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015. (Photo: Tony Ding Associated Press) 
When Jim Harbaugh arrived as Michigan football coach last winter, he removed rivalry references to Michigan State and Ohio State inside Schembechler Hall by taking down countdown clocks and various signs. 
That tone that has continued, as U-M prepares for its first rivalry game on Harbaugh's watch: Saturday against MSU (3:30 p.m., ESPN). He said today that he "couldn't recall" when he took down the clocks and signs. 
And asked about re-establishing Michigan as the in-state power, with the Spartans having won six of the past seven games, Harbaugh was ready to move on. 
"Winning the next game is the goal. That's the most important thing, there's nothing more important than that," he said. "The past? Think about the 'Lion King:' Simba gets hit over the head, and he tells him, 'The past can hurt.' You can either run from it or embrace it and learn from it. I think that's exactly (the way) he said it. Those seem like very wise words." 
Harbaugh understands the importance of the rivalry game, having played in it. He broke his arm in the 1984 loss, then dominated the Spartans in 1985 and 1986, as U-M's quarterback. But he wasn't interested in revisiting those days today. 
"It's a trophy game. We want to get the best grades, win the most awards, want to excel at sports, and this is a game that has a trophy associated with it," Harbaugh said. 
That was the overall tone at today's Michigan news conference. No concern over MSU's beatdowns the past two years. Just the next game on the schedule, which happens to be against MSU. 
"It's shown throughout the whole season: one week at a time, one day at a time, and it's on to the next game after the previous one," U-M fullback Joe Kerridge said. "There's always that extra something, especially from (linebacker Desmond Morgan) and other guys in here about being an in-state rivalry and knowing people at the other schools and things like that. But at the end of the day, it's another game that we have to come and compete." 
So you're fine with the de-emphasis of the rivalry, in favor of the consistency? 
"It's been working so far, and coach Harbaugh knows what he's doing," Kerridge said. "He's been successful."
